definitions: being an artificial substitute or imitation that replaces something real
showing a lack of intelligence or common sense in thinking
created for practice, testing, or demonstration purposes without real function
examples: The store displayed dummy phones on the shelves
They installed dummy security cameras to deter thieves
Don't be such a dummy about basic mathematics
He felt like a dummy after forgetting her birthday
The pilots trained on dummy controls before actual flights
She practiced CPR on a dummy patient yesterday

definitions: having a dull grayish-brown color like that of weathered earth or stone
examples: The dun mare grazed peacefully in the pasture
His dun coat blended with the autumn landscape

definitions: consisting of two parts or components joined together as one unit
allowing communication or operation in both directions simultaneously
examples: They bought a duplex apartment with two separate levels
The duplex house accommodated two families comfortably
The duplex printing feature saves paper and time
Modern phones use duplex communication for clearer calls

definitions: being an exact copy or reproduction of something original
unnecessarily repetitive or redundant in purpose or function
examples: She filed the duplicate forms with the backup records
The duplicate keys were stored in separate locations
We eliminated duplicate efforts between the two departments
The duplicate testing wasted valuable laboratory resources

definitions: able to withstand wear, pressure, or damage while maintaining quality
continuing to exist or function effectively over an extended period
examples: These durable hiking boots lasted through countless trails
The company produces durable goods for industrial use
Their durable friendship survived decades of separation
The treaty established durable peace between the nations

definitions: having a quality of darkness or dimness in color or light
having naturally darker skin tone or complexion
examples: The dusky evening sky signaled approaching nightfall
She wore a dusky rose dress to the gala
The novel described the dusky beauty of the heroine
His dusky complexion reflected his Mediterranean heritage

definitions: covered with or full of fine dry powder or earth particles
having a dull grayish color resembling dust
old-fashioned, neglected, or unused for a long time
examples: The dusty attic hadn't been cleaned in years
Her dusty boots showed evidence of the desert crossing
She chose dusty pink curtains for the bedroom
The dusty blue walls created a calming atmosphere
Those dusty old theories have been thoroughly disproven
The library's dusty volumes contained forgotten knowledge

definitions: conscientiously fulfilling one's obligations and responsibilities as required
performed out of a sense of duty rather than desire or enthusiasm
examples: The dutiful daughter visited her parents every weekend
He was a dutiful employee who never missed work
She gave a dutiful smile at the boring joke
His dutiful applause lacked genuine enthusiasm

definitions: becoming steadily less in size, amount, or strength over time
examples: Their dwindling savings worried them about retirement prospects
The dwindling daylight signaled winter's approaching arrival

definitions: having been colored by soaking in or treating with coloring matter
examples: Her dyed blonde hair looked natural in sunlight
The dyed fabric retained its vibrant color beautifully

definitions: in the process of losing life or approaching death
gradually ceasing to exist, function, or be relevant
happening in the final moments before death
examples: The dying patient requested to see family members
She held the dying bird gently in her hands
Latin is considered a dying language by many
The dying industry struggled to remain profitable
His dying words revealed the location of treasure
Her dying wish was to see the ocean

definitions: characterized by constant activity, energy, and forceful progress
continuously changing, evolving, or developing in response to conditions
relating to forces that produce motion rather than static equilibrium
examples: Her dynamic personality energized the entire team
The dynamic leader transformed the struggling company
The dynamic marketplace requires constant strategic adaptation
They studied dynamic systems in complex environments
Engineers analyzed the dynamic loads on the bridge
Dynamic pressure increases with fluid velocity

definitions: relating to a succession of rulers from the same family line
examples: The dynastic struggles shaped medieval European history
Egypt's dynastic periods span thousands of years

definitions: not operating normally or properly in intended function
characterized by abnormal or unhealthy interpersonal behavior patterns
examples: The dysfunctional equipment delayed production for hours
Their dysfunctional computer system crashed repeatedly
She grew up in a dysfunctional family environment
The dysfunctional relationship caused emotional damage

definitions: affected by dyslexia, a learning difficulty affecting reading and spelling
examples: The dyslexic student received extra time for exams
Many dyslexic individuals excel in creative fields

definitions: relating to an imagined society characterized by great suffering, injustice, or oppression
examples: The dystopian novel depicted a totalitarian future society
His dystopian vision warned of technology's dark potential

definitions: wanting to do or have something very much with enthusiasm
examples: The eager students arrived early for the lecture
She was eager to start her new job

definitions: happening or existing before the present time or before mentioned
coming before in time, order, or position in a sequence
examples: The earlier meeting was cancelled due to weather
Her earlier work showed less artistic maturity
Please refer to my earlier comments about safety
The earlier chapters provide essential background information

definitions: occurring or existing before all others in time or sequence
examples: The earliest settlers arrived three centuries ago
Her earliest memories were of the countryside

definitions: obtained or achieved through work, effort, or action
rightfully deserved as a result of actions or qualities
examples: His earned income exceeded his investment returns significantly
She invested her hard earned savings wisely
The team enjoyed their earned victory after training
He took a well earned vacation after the project

definitions: showing sincere and intense conviction or serious intent
examples: Her earnest plea convinced the committee to reconsider
The earnest young man impressed the interview panel

definitions: unable to leave the earth's surface or atmosphere
lacking imagination or spiritual awareness; mundane and practical
examples: The earthbound spacecraft awaited launch clearance urgently
Humans remained earthbound until the twentieth century
His earthbound thinking limited creative problem solving approaches
Her earthbound concerns focused on practical daily matters

definitions: made of compressed earth, clay, or similar natural materials
examples: The ancient earthen walls still stood after centuries
They stored grain in large earthen vessels

definitions: relating to human life on earth rather than spiritual existence
possible or conceivable within the realm of human experience
examples: He renounced earthly possessions to pursue spiritual enlightenment
Their earthly concerns seemed trivial compared to eternity
There's no earthly reason for such bizarre behavior
What earthly good would that do anyone now

definitions: resembling or suggesting earth or soil in smell, taste, or appearance
direct and uninhibited, especially about bodily functions or sex
examples: The wine had an earthy flavor from the terroir
Mushrooms have a distinctive earthy aroma when cooked
His earthy humor shocked the refined dinner guests
She appreciated his earthy wisdom about life

definitions: made less severe, difficult, or intense than before
having tension, pain, or anxiety reduced or removed
examples: The eased restrictions allowed businesses to reopen gradually
Traffic moved faster on the eased congestion route
His eased expression showed the medication was working
She felt eased after sharing her concerns

definitions: situated in, directed toward, or facing the east direction
coming from the east as wind or weather patterns
examples: The east window catches beautiful morning sunlight daily
They traveled along the east coast for weeks
The east wind brought cold air from the mountains
An east breeze cooled the afternoon heat

definitions: moving or leading toward the east direction
examples: The eastbound train departed from platform three promptly
Heavy eastbound traffic delayed the morning commute significantly

definitions: situated in or moving toward the eastern direction
coming from the east, especially referring to winds
examples: They maintained an easterly course across the ocean
The house has an easterly aspect overlooking fields
Strong easterly winds disrupted flights all day yesterday
The easterly breeze carried salt from the sea

definitions: situated in, directed toward, or coming from the east region
examples: Eastern cultures have different philosophical traditions entirely
The eastern provinces experienced severe drought this year

definitions: situated at the point farthest to the east
examples: The easternmost island receives the sunrise first daily
They reached the easternmost point of the continent

definitions: located in or relating to the eastern part of a city or region
examples: The eastside neighborhood underwent rapid gentrification recently
She opened her eastside clinic last month

definitions: moving, facing, or extending toward the eastern direction
examples: Their eastward journey took them through five countries
The eastward expansion continued throughout the nineteenth century

definitions: achieved without great effort or difficulty in execution
free from worry, pain, or trouble; comfortable and relaxed
vulnerable to being taken advantage of or exploited
examples: The test was easy for well-prepared students
She found an easy solution to the problem
They lived an easy life after winning the lottery
His easy manner made everyone feel welcome
Don't be an easy target for online scammers
She was easy prey for the con artist

definitions: relaxed and tolerant in approach, manner, or attitude toward others
examples: His easygoing nature made him popular among colleagues
The easygoing teacher rarely gave detention to students

definitions: having the deep black color of ebony wood
examples: Her ebony hair gleamed in the bright sunlight
The piano's ebony keys contrasted with white ones

definitions: unconventional and slightly strange in behavior, appearance, or opinions
not placed centrally or not having its axis centrally placed
examples: The eccentric professor wore mismatched socks every day
Her eccentric habits amused and puzzled her neighbors
The eccentric orbit brought the comet unusually close
An eccentric wheel creates irregular rotational movement

definitions: relating to the Christian church or its clergy members
examples: The ecclesiastic authorities issued new guidelines yesterday
He pursued an ecclesiastic career from young age

definitions: relating to the Christian church or its organization and clergy
examples: The ecclesiastical calendar determines religious holiday dates
She studied ecclesiastical history at the seminary

definitions: producing repeated sounds caused by reflection of sound waves
repeating, imitating, or closely resembling something else
examples: The echoing footsteps filled the empty hallway completely
Her voice sounded strange in the echoing cavern
His echoing sentiments showed agreement with the proposal
The design featured echoing patterns throughout the building

definitions: deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad range of sources
examples: Her eclectic taste in music ranged from classical to punk
The restaurant offers an eclectic menu of international dishes

definitions: relating to the relationships between organisms and their environment
examples: The ecological impact of the dam was devastating
Scientists conducted an ecological survey of the region

definitions: relating to economics or the economy of a country or region
justified in terms of profitability or cost-effectiveness
examples: The economic crisis affected millions of workers worldwide
They studied economic theories at the university level
It's not economic to repair such old equipment
The economic choice would be public transportation

definitions: giving good value or service in relation to money spent
using no more of something than is necessary or desired
examples: This economical car uses very little fuel
Buying in bulk is more economical long-term
She was economical with her praise for students
His economical prose style avoided unnecessary words

definitions: feeling or expressing overwhelming happiness or joyful excitement
examples: She was ecstatic when she received the acceptance letter
The ecstatic fans cheered their team's victory loudly

definitions: promoting unity among different Christian churches or religions worldwide
examples: The ecumenical council brought together various Christian denominations
They organized an ecumenical service for community healing

definitions: having a cutting edge or sharp side for cutting
having a border or trim of specified type or material
examples: The double edged sword gleamed in the light
He preferred edged weapons for close combat training
The gold edged invitation cards looked elegantly expensive
Her lace edged handkerchief was a family heirloom

definitions: nervous, anxious, or irritable due to tension or uncertainty
innovative, provocative, or at the forefront of a trend
examples: The edgy atmosphere before the announcement was palpable
She felt edgy waiting for the test results
The edgy artwork challenged traditional aesthetic boundaries completely
His edgy comedy pushed social and political limits

definitions: suitable or safe for eating as food without harm
examples: Not all mushrooms in the forest are edible
The edible flowers decorated the gourmet salad beautifully

definitions: prepared for publication by correcting, revising, or adapting content
examples: The carefully edited manuscript was ready for publication
She submitted the edited version of her thesis
